headline: Baffled scientists make discovery on alien planet that has 'never been seen before' - Manchester Evening News

annotations.paragraph: Scientists have peered through the atmosphere of a planet outside our solar system and discovered weather patterns "like something out of science fiction".
annotations.reason: Introduces the discovery of unusual weather patterns on an exoplanet.

annotations.paragraph: For the first time ever, astronomers mapped the 3D structure of an exoplanet 900 light years from Earth using space telescopes and revealed an unusual climate with record-breaking winds of nearly 100,000 kilometres per hour.
annotations.reason: Provides specific details about the discovery and the methods used.

annotations.paragraph: The planet, named WASP-121b, has been dubbed an "ultra-hot Jupiter" that orbits so close to its star that each year lasts only 30 of our hours on Earth. This creates extreme weather conditions that have fascinated astronomers, marking a major breakthrough for our understanding of the atmosphere and weather of alien worlds.
annotations.reason: Provides context about the planet's characteristics and significance of the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: “This planet’s atmosphere behaves in ways that challenge our understanding of how weather works – not just on Earth, but on all planets. It feels like something out of science fiction,” says Julia Victoria Seidel, a researcher at the European Southern Observatory (ESO) and lead author of the study.
annotations.reason: Provides a direct quote from a lead researcher highlighting the significance of the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: New research reveals that WASP-121b, also known as Tylos, has an atmosphere formed of distinct layers. In the deepest layer, iron-rich gases flow from the scorching side to its cooler side. Above this is a vast jet stream that violently churns the atmosphere up as it crosses the side of the planet that is always facing its sun. An outer layer contains hydrogen gas and is influenced by the jet stream's movement.
annotations.reason: Describes the unique atmospheric conditions of the planet, which are central to the discovery.
This is a placeholder text and does not contribute to the article's content.

annotations.paragraph: Astronomers used the European Southern Observatory’s Very Large Telescope (ESO’s VLT) to probe the exoplanet's atmosphere and were surprised to reveal a climate that "has never been seen before on any planet," challenging our current understanding of weather.
annotations.reason: Details the method used to make the discovery and its significance.

annotations.paragraph: “What we found was surprising: a jet stream rotates material around the planet’s equator, while a separate flow at lower levels of the atmosphere moves gas from the hot side to the cooler side. This kind of climate has never been seen before on any planet,” Dr Seidel said. “Even the strongest hurricanes in the Solar System seem calm in comparison.”
annotations.reason: Provides specific findings and a comparison to known weather phenomena, emphasizing the discovery's uniqueness.

annotations.paragraph: As gases in the planet's atmosphere move, they almost double their speed from 13.7 to 26.8 kilometres per second, whereas powerful jet streams on Earth only reach speeds of around 90 metres per second. Previous discoveries on alien planets, such as WASP-127b, have recorded wind speeds of up to 32,000 kilometres per hour, but it seems Tylos' jet stream shatters these records.
annotations.reason: Provides specific details about the unprecedented speed of the jet stream on the alien planet Tylos.
This is an empty paragraph and does not contribute any information.

annotations.paragraph: Scientists were also surprised to find titanium in the jet stream. Previous observations of the planet suggested this element didn't exist on this alien world, possibly because it was found deep within the atmosphere.
annotations.reason: Reveals a new discovery about the presence of titanium in the planet's atmosphere.

annotations.paragraph: “It’s truly mind-blowing that we’re able to study details like the chemical makeup and weather patterns of a planet at such a vast distance,” says Bibiana Prinoth, a PhD student at Lund University, Sweden, and ESO, who led a companion study.
annotations.reason: Provides a direct quote from a scientist involved in the study, adding credibility and context.
